Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that President Obama made it "legal" for the media to purposely lie to the public.
Understate: The claim understates the actual impact of HR 4310 by suggesting that it allowed propaganda to be used on the citizens of the USA by its own government, when in reality it removed restrictions on news programs funded by the U.S. government.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to back up the assertion that President Obama made it legal for the media to purposely lie.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the Smith-Mundt Modernization Act of 2012, which was part of HR 4310, allows for the media to purposely lie, without providing evidence for this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for the purpose and intent of the Smith-Mundt Modernization Act, such as the aim to educate populations in parts of the world where freedom of speech is suppressed.
